questions.question_text: In general, what is the difference in transmit power between an AP operating at Tx Power Level 1 and the same AP operating at Tx Power Level 3?

discussion.content:
-3dB 1/2mW considerations... 
Tx Power level 1 = 200 mW = 23 dB 
Tx Power level 2 = 100 mW = 20 dB
Tx Power level 3 = 50 mW = 17 dB and so on to Tx Power level 8

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about WiMAX technology? (Choose two.)

choices.C: WiMAX is capable of working as a long-range system over several miles.
choices.D: WiMAX works only for licensed frequencies.
choices.B: Typically, fixed WiMAX networks have a higher gain direction antenna installed near the client.

discussion.content:
A is not correct because 802.11i specified WPA2 for authentication. Wi-Max i specified by 802.16.
D is not correct because Wi-MAX can use licenced or unlicensed frequencies, 
but typically use frequencies outside the unlicensed 2.4ghz and 5ghz band to avoid interfering with WI-FI networks.

questions.answer_description:
Most clients enable you to associate to a detected network (broadcasted SSID) or configure a specific profile. In all cases, you must configure the network name
(SSID), the operating mode (ad-hoc or infrastructure), and some security settings (that will be different depending on whether the SSID uses Pre-Shared Key
Security or Enterprise [EAP/802.1x] security).

discussion.content:
I think ACD is correct, but G could also be correct.

You need the SSID to connect to any WLAN so A is correct.
The client cannot select the channel, so B is not correct.
You need to be within range of the AP with adequate signal, so C is correct.
"enterprise" Wireless networks are defined by Cisco as using 802.1X/EAP credentials, so D is correct.
E is not correct because PSK is not permitted with Enterprise Wireless networks.
F is not correct because many authentication methods do not require a web page.
G could be correct since enterprise mode requires 802.1x, but can use either WPA or WPA2.

I don't like this question becuase of the vague use of the term "enterprise".
If they are referring to "Enterprise Mode", then G could also be a correct answer.

questions.question_text: Which three items do you need to establish a wireless connection to an enterprise wireless network? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
At 6dB : mW = 3.98=4mW them original tx power = 4mW + 3.98 = 7.98mW
correct answer is 8mW that is A.

questions.question_text: An access point is currently transmitting at 4 mW. The customer needs to increase its signal strength by 6 dB to create a larger wireless cell. What should the new transmit power be?

discussion.content: Answer is D or B? I think D.

choices.C: This configuration is unsupported and the Cisco Wireless Control System generates alarms continuously until the configuration is corrected.
choices.B: Some wireless client drivers might not handle complex SSID settings and may be unable to associate to the WLAN.
choices.D: This configuration is common for migrating from WPA to WPA2. No problem is associated with using this configuration.
choices.A: The overhead associated with supporting both encryption methods degrades client throughput significantly.

questions.question_text: What is the impact of configuring a single SSID to support TKIP and AES encryption simultaneously?
questions.answer_description:
AES encryption uses hardware so there is almost no overhead when using it. TKIP is based on software. So when we support both TKIP and AES the client throughput will not significantly degrade -> A is not correct.
When choosing both AES and TKIP, the router will support both encryption algorithms. Because not all wireless NICs support AES, some only support TKIP, so this option is probably the best choice -> B is not correct.
As the picture below, Cisco Wireless Control System does support both simultaneously -> C is not correct.
